citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has not developed a written environmental enrichment plan for the newly acquired Titi monkeys at the facility.
Implementing documented enrichment protocols ensure adequate provisions are in place to promote the psychological
well-being of the non-human primates at a facility. An enrichment plan must be developed, documented, followed, and
approved by the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for individually housed non-
human primates that are unable to see or hear other non-human primates of their own or compatible species.
Correct by October 6, 2023.

The facility has not conducted water quality testing of the back holding pool currently housing one harbor seal and her
pup. Both harbor seals are currently confined to the one pool to separate the new pup from the sea lions that inhabit the
main exhibit pool. Although the facility still conducts routine water testing from the main pool, no samples have been taken
from the secondary pool that now serves as the primary enclosure for the harbor seals.
Routine water sampling and testing is essential to uphold water quality standards. Doing so identifies quality control
problems in a timely manner to prevent conditions that are harmful to the animals that inhabit the pools. Water in all pools
shall be sampled and tested for coliform counts at least weekly to maintain water quality standards.
Correct by October 2, 2023.

One container of yogurt stored in the refrigerator has expired. This yogurt has been used to administer medications for the
brown bear at the facility. While the facility recently purchased the container of yogurt and anticipated its expiration date to
be further out, the facility representative was unaware the date had passed until notice during the inspection.
Feeding food items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld
and preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive
value to maintain all animals in good health.
Correct by September 29, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility has not developed a written environmental enrichment plan for the newly acquired Titi monkeys at the facility. 
Implementing documented enrichment protocols ensure adequate provisions are in place to promote the psychological 
well-being of the non-human primates at a facility. An enrichment plan must be developed, documented, followed, and 
approved by the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for individually housed non-
human primates that are unable to see or hear other non-human primates of their own or compatible species. 
Correct by October 6, 2023. 
3.106(a) 
   
Water quality. 
The facility has not conducted water quality testing of the back holding pool currently housing one harbor seal and her 
pup. Both harbor seals are currently confined to the one pool to separate the new pup from the sea lions that inhabit the 
main exhibit pool. Although the facility still conducts routine water testing from the main pool, no samples have been taken 
from the secondary pool that now serves as the primary enclosure for the harbor seals. 
Routine water sampling and testing is essential to uphold water quality standards. Doing so identifies quality control 
problems in a timely manner to prevent conditions that are harmful to the animals that inhabit the pools. Water in all pools 
shall be sampled and tested for coliform counts at least weekly to maintain water quality standards. 
Correct by October 2, 2023. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
One container of yogurt stored in the refrigerator has expired. This yogurt has been used to administer medications for the 
brown bear at the facility. While the facility recently purchased the container of yogurt and anticipated its expiration date to 
be further out, the facility representative was unaware the date had passed until notice during the inspection.  
Feeding food items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld 
and preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive 
value to maintain all animals in good health. 
Correct by September 29, 2023.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
